Summary: Checkout Page → City field accepts non-alphabetic characters
Description:
*Steps to Reproduce:*
# Go to the Checkout page.
# Locate the City input field.
# Enter non-alphabetic characters, such as:
# Numbers: “Cairo123”
# Symbols: “@Cairo!”
# Click Continue or attempt to submit the form.

*Expected Results:*
The City field should only accept alphabetic characters and spaces (e.g., “New York”), and should reject numbers or special symbols with a validation error.

*Actual Results:*
The system accepts non-alphabetic input in the City field without any validation message or restriction.

Summary: System → Fails to handle leading and trailing spaces in input fields
Description:
*Steps to Reproduce*
# Navigate to any form (e.g., Login, Sign-Up, or Checkout page)
# Enter valid input data with leading or trailing spaces in one or more fields — for example:
# Email: " user@example.com "
# Name: " John "
# Postal Code: " 12345 "
# Submit the form.

*Expected Results:*
The system should automatically trim leading and trailing spaces before validating the input, treating " user@example.com " as "user@example.com".

*Actual Results:*
The system fails to trim leading and trailing spaces, causing valid inputs to be rejected or processed incorrectly.

Summary: Checkout Page → Postal code field accepts alphabetic characters
Description:
*Steps to Reproduce:*
# Go to the Checkout page.
# Locate the Postal Code input field.
# Enter alphabetic characters (e.g., “ABCD”) instead of numeric values.
# Click Continue or attempt to submit the form.

*Expected Results:*
The Postal Code field should only accept valid postal code formats (typically numeric or alphanumeric depending on the country) and should reject purely alphabetic input with a validation message.

*Actual Results:*
The system accepts alphabetic input in the Postal Code field and allows the form to be submitted without displaying any validation error.

Summary: Cart Page → Reducing item quantity to 1 does not update total price
Description:
*Steps to Reproduce:*
# Go to the Cart page.
# Add a product with quantity greater than 1 (e.g., 3).
# Manually reduce the quantity back to 1 using the input field or quantity control.
# Observe the item total and cart total.

*Expected Results:*
When reducing the quantity to 1, the system should recalculate and update the item subtotal and overall cart total immediately.

*Actual Results:*
When changing the quantity from more than 1 back to 1, the total price does not update, and the system continues showing the previous total amount.

Summary: Cart Page → Quantity field cannot be cleared manually without selecting the number first
Description:
*Steps to Reproduce:*
# Go to the Cart page after adding any product.
# Click on the Quantity field to edit the number.
# Attempt to delete the existing number (e.g., “1”) using the backspace or delete key.
# Try to type a new number without selecting the existing value first.

*Expected Results:*
Users should be able to delete the existing quantity freely using backspace or delete, and then enter a new number directly.
 [^WhatsApp Video 2025-11-09 at 21.13.00_69ba440a.mp4] 
*Actual Results:*
The system does not allow deleting the number unless the user selects the entire value first.
If the user presses a number key without selecting the old value, the digits are added to the existing quantity (e.g., “1” → “11” → “111”), making it difficult to enter single-digit quantities.

Summary: Browsing Products → Page does not auto-scroll to top after switching pages
Description:
*Steps to Reproduce:*
# Go to the Product Listing page.
# Scroll down to view products near the bottom of the page.
# Click to navigate to the next page (e.g., Page 2 or Page 3).

*Expected Results:*
After switching to a new page, the system should automatically scroll to the top of the page so that users can immediately see th [^WhatsApp Video 2025-11-09 at 21.01.29_6b75c2de.mp4] e new product list and page header.

*Actual Results:*
When switching pages, the system remains at the previous scroll position, displaying the bottom of the new page.
Users must manually scroll up to view the new content.

Summary: Browsing Products → System resets to first page and first product after navigating back from product details
Description:
*Steps to Reproduce:*
# Go to the Product Listing page. [^WhatsApp Video 2025-11-09 at 20.53.20_99015849.mp4] 
# Navigate to page 2 (or any page other than the first).
# Select any product from that page to open its Product Details.
# Click the Back button in the browser or use site navigation to return to the product list.

*Expected Results:*
The user should return to the same page and product position they were viewing before (e.g., page 2, same scroll position).

*Actual Results:*
After navigating back, the system returns to the first page of the product list and highlights or focuses on the first product, instead of restoring the previous page and position.

Summary: Filters  → Applied filters are cleared when navigating back from a product details page
Description:
*Steps to Reproduce:*
Go to the homepage.
Apply one or more filters (e.g., category, price range, brand, etc.).
Click on any product to open its Product Details page.
Click the Back button in the browser or on the page to return to the product listing.

Expected Results:
The previously applied filters should persist after returning to the product listing page, showing only the filtered products.

Actual Results:
All applied filters are cleared, and the system reloads the full product list, forcing the user to reapply filters manually.

Summary: Filter -> Selected sort option not displayed in dropdown after choosing filter
Description:
*Steps to reproduce:*
# open filters in homepage 
# select any type of sorting from the sort dropdown menu

*Expected Results:*
The selected sort type should remain visible in the dropdown field after being chosen (e.g., “Price: Low to High”), clearly indicating the active sorting criteria.

*Actual Results:*
After selecting a sort type, the dropdown closes but the selected option does not appear in the dropdown field.
The user cannot tell which sorting option is currently applied.

Summary: Login Page → Error message does not refresh on repeated invalid login attempts
Description:
*Steps to Reproduce:*
# Open the Login page.
# Enter an invalid email or password combination and click Login.
# Observe the error message displayed (e.g., “Invalid email or password”).
# Without refreshing the page, try another invalid input and click Login again.

*Expected Results:*
The system should refresh the error message or provide a visual response (e.g., button click animation or updated text) after each invalid attempt, indicating that the login process has been re-evaluated.

*Actual Results:*
The error message remains static and does not refresh after repeated invalid attempts.
The Login button also shows no visual feedback, making it appear as if the system is unresponsive or frozen.

Summary: Login Page → System allows login when email case sensitivity is mismatched
Description:
*Steps to Reproduce:*
# Go to the Login page.
# Enter a registered email address using different letter casing (e.g., “Karim@outlook.com” instead of karim@outlook.com”).
# Enter the correct password associated with that account.
# Click Login.

*Expected Results:*
The system should treat the email address as case-sensitive (if designed to be strict) and reject mismatched casing — displaying an appropriate error message (e.g., Invalid email or password).

*Actual Results:*
The system accepts the mismatched email casing and successfully logs the user into their account.

Summary: Sign-Up Page → Password strength meter text and layout are misaligned
Description:
*Steps to Reproduce:*

# Open the *Sign-Up* page.
# Enter different passwords of varying complexity (weak, moderate, strong, etc.).
# Observe the password strength section and meter below the password field.

*Expected Results:*
The password strength indicator should display a *single, clearly formatted strength label* (e.g., “Weak,” “Moderate,” “Strong”) and a *progress bar* that visually reflects the strength level.

*Actual Results:*
All strength labels (“Weak,” “Moderate,” “Strong,” “Very Strong,” “Excellent”) appear simultaneously, overlapping and misaligned, making the indicator unclear and unprofessional.

Summary: Sign-Up Page → Postal code field accepts alphabetic and special characters
Description:
*Steps to Reproduce:*
# Open the Sign-Up page.
# Locate the Postal Code input field.
# Enter alphabetic characters (e.g., “ABCD”) or special symbols (e.g., “@#$%”).
# Click Sign Up or submit the form.

*Expected Results:*
The Postal Code field should only accept valid postal code formats — typically numeric or alphanumeric depending on region — and reject special symbols or purely alphabetic input.

*Actual Results:*
The system accepts alphabetic and special characters in the Postal Code field without displaying any validation error.

Summary: Signup Page → Missing “Confirm Password” field during account registration
Description:
*Steps to Reproduce:*
# Open the Signup page of the Tool Shop website.
# Fill in all available fields (name, email, password, etc.).
# Observe the form structure before submitting.

*Expected Results:*
The signup form should include a “Confirm Password” field to verify that the user entered their password correctly and prevent accidental typos.

*Actual Results:*
The signup form only includes a single Password field with no option to confirm it.
This can lead to user frustration or failed logins due to mistyped passwords.
